top_comment.text:
It's a shame people cannot see that "graceless" dance is something Spike 
Jonze made on purpose. I assure you, all the girls in the video really know 
how to dance. I mean, this happened there; this is a live video, they only 
had one chance to make it right and they wouldn't risk an Arcade Fire 
performance with any ammateur girl. The point of the video is to show an 
internal freedom, a catharsis through the dance; and this "awful" dance 
express it all without words, or a great story needed.﻿
top_comment.author: enriquekikdu

comments.text:
Well said. To add - One thing people are not getting is Jonze wanted to 
epitomize what YouTube is all about when it comes to making a homemade 
video in one shot. Add some music and come up with an idea and upload it. 
It's not about the Madonna finished product here people! Relax! PS: Thanks 
Greta, dance team and AF and Spike and focused  camera crew!

comments.author: Claire Fadness

comments.text:
hipster:
Hipsters are a subculture of men and women typically in their 20's and 30's 
that value independent thinking, counter-culture, progressive politics, an 
appreciation of art and indie-rock, creativity, intelligence, and witty 
banter. The greatest concentrations of hipsters can be found living in the 
Williamsburg, Wicker Park, and Mission District neighborhoods of major 
cosmopolitan centers such as New York, Chicago, and San Francisco 
respectively. Although "hipsterism" is really a state of mind,it is also 
often intertwined with distinct fashion sensibilities. Hipsters reject the 
culturally-ignorant attitudes of mainstream consumers, and are often be 
seen wearing vintage and thrift store inspired fashions, tight-fitting 
jeans, old-school sneakers, and sometimes thick rimmed glasses. Both 
hipster men and women sport similar androgynous hair styles that include 
combinations of messy shag cuts and asymmetric side-swept bangs. Such 
styles are often associated with the work of creative stylists at urban 
salons, and are usually too "edgy" for the culturally-sheltered mainstream 
consumer. The "effortless cool" urban bohemian look of a hipster is 
exemplified in Urban Outfitters and American Apparel ads which cater 
towards the hipster demographic. Despite misconceptions based on their 
aesthetic tastes, hipsters tend to be well educated and often have liberal 
arts degrees, or degrees in maths and sciences, which also require certain 
creative analytical thinking abilities.
comments.author: Claire Fadness

comments.author: Roberto Campos Jordán

comments.text:
I think you're missing the point here: the purpose of the video clearly 
isn't to show the band playing, otherwise they wouldn't have chosen Spike 
Jonze to direct it.
The DANCING is exactly what they wanted it to be and the fabulous Greta 
Gerwig (watch the movie Frances Ha) is great at it. It's the 
"dance-like-nobody's-watching" type of dancing (which may be downright 
embarrassing at times, you're right about that, but it's also very fun to 
look at), and it's just perfect if you put it into the video's context, 
because it expresses the liberty (which encompasses both fear and relief) 
that follows a break-up (that you see at the beginning of the video), 
however painful this may be.
comments.author: EdoRaven Z.

top_comment.text:
I found funny the coments that say that the dance is stupid and has no 
sense. But i ask you ? Is it supposed to make sense? That is just her way 
of letting go of her heartbreak. She dances like no one was watching and 
she feels better with it. Doesn´t matter if she makes the right moves or 
not. She is dancing her own way. I think that this video can be a great 
message for life. We all do things our way and it's not wrong or right. 
It's just our way of living. And like in the video, we all have our ways of 
moving on with life after a bad thing happen.﻿
top_comment.author: Tiago Fonseca

comments.text:
I didn't realize that I watched Greta Gerwig's performance just few days 
before this music video came out. She was in a movie called "Frances Ha", 
exactly the same sort of character: she can't "properly" dance. But we have 
to ask ourselves, what's the purpose of dance? It is to express our 
emotion, to experience our body, and communicate with the world. In that 
sense, she did a perfect job; I cried over this video several times because 
I'm experiencing a break up at the moment, and every scene in this video 
tells me something. Yes, that's exactly how we respond to those kind of 
events, we were lost, we didn't know how to recover, didn't know what's the 
next step, yet we responded with instinct, we danced like no one else is 
watching. We express ourselves with awkward movements, and that's might be 
what Spike wants us to feel. BTW, I have a thought that "afterlife" is 
actually not about afterlife, it's about saperation, and death is just a 
metaphor.
comments.author: Shirly Zhang

comments.text:
Exactly how I feel. At first I thought, this girl is not that good of a 
dancer, but after repeated views it makes more sense that she's not. She 
just found a way to get over some bad news. Her acting is another thing. 
That opening scene is just brilliant and even her cathartic smile at the 
end was very well done. I haven't seen the other live videos from the 
awards, but from what I read Arcade Fire did it best. Makes sense. They 
have experimented with interactive videos before. And, oh yeah, AF is the 
freaking best.

top_comment.text:
In case you missed it three weeks ago (like I did), Arcade Fire performed 
at the YouTube Music Awards (which I didn’t watch, because who cares about 
Lady Gaga or Eminem).

But Spike Jonze directed a live music video, starring Greta Gerwig (whose 
name is an anagram for “Great Wigger”, and by the way, “anagram” is an 
anagram for “arm a nag”), and it was live! And there were trees, and she 
was dancing, and it was also Arcade Fire playing and Spike Jonze directing, 
so that was pretty enjoyable.﻿

comments.author: AV pr_service

top_comment.text:
I think this is a solid performance, and I think the choreography itself is 
great, but the general vibe of it doesn't match up with how the song 
resonates with me emotionally. I think it—along with the rest of the tracks 
on the 2nd disc of Reflektor—is a pretty melancholy song despite its dancy 
beat. I interpreted the song to be about trying so hard to grasp at the 
straws of a failing relationship that you end up making things worse, 
resorting to "scream[ing] and shout[ing]" because nothing else is working. 
The opening line—Afterlife, oh my God what an awful word—connotes pretty 
strongly the idea that something is over, but the speaker isn't ready or 
able to move past it just yet. By contrast, this performance seems to 
suggest a "dance your blues away!" aesthetic which seems at odds with my 
own interpretation of the song.

That's just my own interpretation of the music, and one of the great things 
about art is that everyone can have their own experience and their own 
interpretation. I'm not trying to say my view is "right"; I'm just 
reflecting a bit on what I thought of this video.﻿
top_comment.author: Victoly

comments.text:
+Victoly I really appreciated your interpretation, although I felt a strong 
emotional connection with this song the way it was interpreted here.  Even 
though it's "upbeat" I still felt it was really melancholy, even with her 
dancing.  Her facial expression and overall emotion really resonated with 
me  - especially when I went through a pretty awful breakup a few years 
ago. 

You are right. We each have our own interpretation. :)  That's what makes 
it all so wonderful. Thank you for sharing yours!
comments.author: Misael Legare

comments.text:
This isn't something Arcade Fire did; it's something Spike Jonze did.

AF are a great band, but I think you're putting them on too much of a 
creative pedestal. They have moments of symbolism, but also moments of 
straightforward music performance.
comments.author: Victoly

comments.text:
You've kind of taken my quote out of context.
What I was trying to get at was that the song lyrics and choreography tell 
two different parts of the same story. The song lyrics describe the 
breakdown of the relationship up to the point at the beginning of the 
choreography. In the song, the narrator is still trying unsuccessfully to 
save the relationship. The choreography picks up on one possible 
interpretation of the narrative after the song ends, There is The dancing 
at the end is coming out the other side.

I don't mean to be rude, but offering up "she's happy" doesn't really jibe 
with the way Arcade Fire operates. They put symbolism in EVERYTHING they 
do, That includes their live performances.You can argue that my take is 
incorrect, but unless you offer up something substantive as reason or your 
own alternative theory, you're just being contrarian.
comments.author: BromleyGaffer

comments.text:
"She hasn't moved on completely, but the absence no longer presses down on 
her and controls her life."

We're all entitled to our interpretations, but that's too much "reading-in" 
for me. We have no definitive indication of any of this. What we see is the 
protagonist dancing and smiling with a group of children. That's pretty 
open to interpretation, but I'm inclined to take an Occam's Razor approach 
and just think "she's happy".

In any event, the "absence pressing down on [someone]" IS actually the vibe 
I get from the song, so—for me personally—your interpretation of the 
dance/choreography is still discordant with what I get from the music.
comments.author: Victoly

comments.text:
+BromleyGaffer Interesting. The only comment I thought to make was that, 
and it's a minute detail, it's awkward that she doesn't take her jacket 
off... It actually restrains her movement at times
comments.author: baconbutterburger

+BromleyGaffer Makes total sense to me. She is beautiful doing this to. I

comments.author: Nelson Olivier jr

comments.text:
Just playing Devil's advocate here, but what if the frenetic nature of the 
performance isn't meant to convey a "dance the blues away attitude", but a 
way to release all the pent up energy that would otherwise be spent on a 
now-absent partner. In the beginning of the video, Gerwig's character tries 
to internalize that energy and finds she can't. Even the first few big 
movements are directed inwards. She then uses that energy to strike 
outwards in order to  distract herself, but it's a temporary fix and we see 
cracks in her veneer throughout the performance.

To a certain extent I think it's also about the fact she is now completely 
unrestrained. Her old world has collapsed and she needs to construct a new 
one, only she's not sure yet how to do that. In the forest, it's dark and 
frighting, but it's also exhilarating to be on a path and not know where 
it's going. When that nervous energy subsides, she's left alone in the 
cold, dark forest again.

The end, I think, is her reaching some kind of equilibrium. She hasn't 
moved on completely, but the absence no longer presses down on her and 
controls her life. The young girls could represent the protagonist's 
rediscovered sense of self after being defined for so long as part of a 
pair. She remembers who she is and why there is still reason to keep going 
(dancing).

Just my two cents. :)
comments.author: BromleyGaffer

comments.text:
Just sharing my views, 'cause that's what comments sections are for. Nobody 
is forcing you to read what I have to say?
